company.name: Cash Today, Ltd.
company.address: Northway House, 1379 High Road, Whetstone, London N20 9LP
company.business_description: Cash Today, Ltd. participates in the advertising and extension of credit to consumers in the form of high-fee, short-term payday loans, and the collection of those loans. The company operates under multiple trade names including Route 66 Funding, Global Financial Services International, Ltd., Interim Cash, Ltd., and BIG-INT, Ltd.

case_info.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b), and the Truth in Lending Act (TILA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 1601-1666j

complaint.factual_background: Defendants, operating primarily from the United Kingdom under names such as Cash Today, Route 66 Funding, and Global Financial Services International, offered high-fee short-term payday loans of up to $500 to U.S. consumers via websites and telephone, without providing any written disclosure of loan terms such as the APR, payment schedule, or total of payments. When consumers — believing they had fully repaid their loans — closed their bank accounts to stop further debits, defendants launched deceptive and abusive collection campaigns, falsely threatening arrest, imprisonment, lawsuits, and wage garnishment. Defendants also harassed consumers at their workplaces with repeated calls using obscene and threatening language, and disclosed consumers' purported debts to coworkers and employers. Many of the loans were illegal and unenforceable under state payday lending laws, yet defendants falsely represented that consumers had a legal obligation to repay them in full.

representations_made.description: Defendants represented that consumers can borrow up to $500 within 24 hours with no credit check, proof of income, or documentation required
representations_made.quoted_text: 2 18. Doing business as Cash Today, Route 66 Funding, Global Financial Services 3 International, Ltd., Interim Cash, Ltd., and BIG-INT, Ltd., and through Web sites such as 4 www.cash2day4u.com, defendants, operating primarily from the United Kingdom, offer United 5 States consumers payday loans of $500.00 or less. “Payday” loans are the common name used 6 for short-term, high-fee unsecured loans, often made to consumers to provide needed funds in 7 anticipation of an upcoming paycheck. On the Web site, defendants represent that consumers 8 can borrow up to $500.00 within 24 hours, with no credit check, proof of income, or 9 documentation required.

representations_made.description: Defendants falsely represented to consumers that they have a legal obligation to repay the loans, even where the loans were illegal or unenforceable under state law
representations_made.quoted_text: 17 those consumers’ bank accounts. Defendants falsely represent to consumers that they have a 18 legal obligation to repay the loans, even though many consumers have no such obligation, 19 because defendants’ payday loans do not comply with the payday lending laws of those 20 consumers’ states or because defendants are not licensed to make consumer loans in those states.

representations_made.description: Defendants falsely represented that they could and would have consumers arrested or imprisoned, or would take formal legal action such as filing suit, seizing property, or garnishing wages
representations_made.quoted_text: 24 unenforceable. Defendants also intimidate consumers, falsely representing that defendants can 25 and will have them arrested or imprisoned, or falsely representing that defendants will take 26 formal legal action against them such as filing a law suit, seizing or attaching their property, or 27 garnishing their wages. In fact, in many instances, defendants cannot take such legal action and, 28 in any event, have no intention of doing so.

representations_made.description: Defendants told consumers that because they are located in the United Kingdom, they do not have to comply with U.S. laws
representations_made.quoted_text: 10 defendants routinely tell consumers that because they are located in the United Kingdom, they 11 do not have to comply with US laws.

counts.title: Deceptive Collection Practices
counts.representation: Defendants represented that (A) consumers can be arrested or imprisoned for failing to pay; (B) consumers have a legal obligation to pay defendants the full amount claimed; and (C) defendants can and will take formal legal action such as filing suit, seizing property, or garnishing wages
counts.fact: In truth: (A) consumers cannot be arrested or imprisoned for failing to pay defendants; (B) in numerous instances consumers do not have a legal obligation to pay the full amount claimed; and (C) in numerous instances defendants cannot and do not take formal legal action against consumers
counts.conclusion: Defendants' representations are false and misleading and constitute deceptive acts or practices in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

counts.title: Unfair Collection Practices
counts.representation: Defendants harassed consumers, coworkers, employers, and other third parties by (A) continuously and repeatedly calling consumers and others at consumers' places of employment; (B) using obscene, profane, threatening, or otherwise abusive language; and (C) disclosing the existence of consumers' purported debts to coworkers, employers, and other third parties
counts.fact: These acts cause or are likely to cause substantial injury to consumers which is not reasonably avoidable by consumers themselves and is not outweighed by countervailing benefits to consumers or competition
counts.conclusion: Defendants' acts and practices constitute unfair acts or practices in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

counts.title: Violations of TILA and Regulation Z
counts.representation: Defendants extended closed-end credit to consumers without making required disclosures
counts.fact: Defendants failed to disclose, clearly and conspicuously in writing before consummation of the loan transaction, the amount financed, itemization of the amount financed, the finance charge, the annual percentage rate, the payment schedule, the total of payments, and any late payment fees, as required by TILA and Regulation Z
counts.conclusion: Defendants violated Sections 121 and 128 of TILA, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1631 and 1638, and Sections 226.17 and 226.18 of Regulation Z, each of which also constitutes a violation of the FTC Act under TILA Section 108(c)

counts.title: Failure to Disclose Material Facts (Nevada NRS § 598.0923(2))
counts.representation: Defendants sold loans without providing the provisions of the loan contract, including the interest rate
counts.fact: Nevada Revised Statutes § 598.0923(2) requires disclosure of material facts in connection with the sale of services; defendants failed to disclose material loan terms
counts.conclusion: Each of defendants' acts or practices which failed to disclose a material fact in connection with the sale of services is a violation of Chapter 598 of the Nevada Revised Statutes, NRS § 598.0923(2)

counts.title: Violation of State or Federal Statute Relating to Sale of Services (Nevada NRS § 598.0923(3))
counts.representation: Defendants' failure to disclose loan terms, their false representations in collecting debts, and their harassment and abuse of consumers in collecting debts constitute violations of federal and state law
counts.fact: Nevada Revised Statutes § 598.0923(3) makes it a deceptive trade practice to violate a state or federal statute or regulation relating to the sale of services; defendants violated Section 5(a) of the FTC Act
counts.conclusion: Each of defendants' acts or practices which violate a state or federal statute or regulation relating to the sale of services is a violation of Chapter 598 of the Nevada Revised Statutes, NRS § 598.0923(3)

counts.title: Operating Without Required Licenses (Nevada NRS § 598.0923(1))
counts.representation: Defendants sold loans in Nevada without acquiring the required licenses from the Nevada Financial Institution
counts.fact: Nevada Revised Statutes Chapters 675 and/or 604A require defendants to obtain licenses to sell loans in Nevada; defendants did not acquire those licenses
counts.conclusion: Each of defendants' acts or practices of selling loans without acquiring the necessary licenses from the Nevada Financial Institution is a violation of Chapter 598 of the Nevada Revised Statutes, NRS § 598.0923(1)

definitions.Closed-end credit: "Closed-end credit" means consumer credit other than open-end credit, and "open-end credit" means "consumer credit extended by a creditor under a plan in which: (i) the creditor reasonably contemplates repeated transactions; (ii) the creditor may impose a finance charge from time to time on an outstanding unpaid balance; and (iii) the amount of credit that may be extended to the consumer during the term of the plan (up to any limit set by the creditor) is generally made available to the extent that any outstanding balance is repaid." 12 C.F.R. §§ 226.2(a)(10) and (a)(20).
definitions.Collection of debts: any activity the principal purpose of which is to collect or attempt to collect, directly or indirectly, debts owed or due or asserted to be owed or due.
definitions.Consumer: an actual or potential purchaser, customer, or borrower.
definitions.Corporate Defendants: "Corporate Defendants" means Cash Today, Ltd., The Heathmill Village, Ltd., Leads Global, Inc., Waterfront Investments, Inc., ACH Cash, Inc., HBS Services, Inc., Lotus Leads, Inc., Roving International, Inc., First4Leads, Inc., and The Harris Holdings, Ltd., and their successors and assigns.
definitions.Clearly and Conspicuously: "Clearly and Conspicuously" means: a. if presented in writing, the information shall be in a type size and location sufficient for an ordinary consumer to read and comprehend it, and shall be disclosed in a manner that would be easily recognizable and understandable in language and syntax to an ordinary consumer. If the information is contained in a multi-page print document, the disclosure shall appear on the first page; b. if presented orally, the information shall be disclosed in a volume, cadence, and syntax sufficient for an ordinary consumer to hear and comprehend; and c. nothing contrary to any information disclosed shall be imparted at or near the time of disclosure. Further, a subsequent disclosure made orally or in writing only limits or qualifies a prior disclosure and cannot cure a false claim.
definitions.Creditor: "Creditor" means a person who regularly extends consumer credit that is subject to a finance charge or is payable by written agreement in more than four installments (not including a down payment), and to whom the obligation is initially payable, either on the face of the note or contract, or by agreement when there is no contract. 12 C.F.R. § 226.2(a)(17).
definitions.Defendants: "Defendants" means the Corporate Defendants and Individual Defendants, individually, collectively, or in any combination.
definitions.Debt: "Debt" means any obligation or alleged obligation of a consumer to pay money arising out of a transaction in which the money, property, or services that are the subject of the transaction are primarily for personal, family, or household purposes, whether or not such obligation has been reduced to judgment.
definitions.Document: "Document" is synonymous in meaning and equal in scope to the usage of the term in Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 34(a), and includes writings, drawings, graphs, charts, photographs, audio and video recordings, computer records, and other data compilations from which information can be obtained and translated, if necessary, through detection devices into reasonably usable form. A draft or non-identical copy is a separate document within the meaning of the term.
definitions.Individual Defendants: "Individual Defendants" means Aaron Gershfield, Ivor Gershfield, and each of them, by whatever names each might be known.
definitions.Person: "Person" means any individual, group, unincorporated association, limited or general partnership, corporation, or other business entity.
definitions.Regulation Z: "Regulation Z" means the regulation the Federal Reserve Board ("FRB") promulgated to implement TILA, 12 C.F.R. Part 226, as currently promulgated or as it may hereafter be amended. The term also includes the FRB Official Staff Commentary on Regulation Z, 12 C.F.R. Part 226, Supp. I, as currently promulgated or as it may hereafter be amended. The terms "annual percentage rate," "consumer credit," and "finance charge" are defined as set forth in Sections 226.2, 226.4, and 226.22 of Regulation Z, 12 C.F.R. §§ 226.2, 226.4, and 226.22.
definitions.Third Party: "Third Party" means any person or entity that is not a consumer including, but not limited to, any parent of a non-minor consumer, or any child, relative, neighbor, coworker, or employer of a consumer.

provisions.title: Employee Monitoring by Defendants
provisions.summary: Defendants must take reasonable steps to monitor and ensure that all employees and independent contractors engaged in extending consumer credit or collecting debts comply with Sections I through V of this Order, including listening to calls, maintaining a customer response center, investigating complaints, and taking corrective action.

requirements.description: Must not fail to take reasonable steps sufficient to monitor and ensure that all employees and independent contractors engaged in marketing, extending consumer credit, the collection of debts, or other customer service functions comply with Sections I through V of this Order; such steps shall include adequate monitoring of calls with customers, and shall also include at a minimum: (1) listening to oral representations made by persons engaged in marketing or extending consumer loans and/or the collection of debts or other customer service functions; (2) providing a customer response center available by toll-free number or by email that will receive and respond to customer complaints and inquiries within a reasonable and specified time period; and (3) ascertaining the number and nature of customer complaints regarding transactions in which each employee or independent contractor is involved

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC is authorized to monitor and investigate compliance with this Order by requiring Defendants to submit written reports, produce documents, appear for depositions, provide access to business locations, and by posing as consumers or suppliers.

requirements.description: Within ten (10) days of receipt of written notice from a representative of the Commission, Defendants each shall submit additional written reports sworn to under penalty of perjury; produce documents for inspection and copying; appear for deposition; and provide entry during normal business hours to any business location in each Defendant's possession or direct or indirect control to inspect the business operation

provisions.title: Record Keeping Provisions
provisions.summary: For a period of six years from entry of this Order, Defendants must create, retain, and secure records relating to consumer credit and debt collection, including accounting records, personnel records, customer files, complaints, marketing materials, and all documents necessary to demonstrate full compliance.

requirements.description: For a period of six (6) years from the date of entry of this Order, Defendants are restrained and enjoined from failing to create, retain, and secure accounting records that reflect the monies loaned and collected, revenues generated, and the disbursement of such revenues

provisions.title: Distribution of Order
provisions.summary: For a period of three years from entry of this Order, Corporate Defendants must deliver copies of the Order to all principals, officers, employees, agents, and representatives; Individual Defendants who control a business must do the same; and all recipients must sign dated acknowledgments of receipt within 30 days.

requirements.description: For a period of three (3) years from entry of this Order, each Corporate Defendant must deliver a copy of this Order to: (1) all of its principals, officers, directors, and managers; (2) all of its employees, agents, and representatives who engage in conduct related to the subject matter of the Order; and (3) any business entity resulting from any change in structure. For current personnel, delivery shall be within five (5) days of service of this Order; for new personnel, delivery shall occur prior to them assuming their responsibilities; for any business entity resulting from any change in structure, delivery shall be at least ten (10) days prior to the change in structure

provisions.title: Acknowledgment of Receipt of Order
provisions.summary: Each Defendant must submit a truthful sworn statement to the Commission acknowledging receipt of this Order within five business days of receipt of the Order as entered by the Court.

requirements.description: Each Defendant, within five (5) business days of receipt of this Order as entered by the Court, must submit to the Commission a truthful sworn statement acknowledging receipt of this Order
